display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 78px; height: 1px; padding-top: 105px; margin-left: 161px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: center;

display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 212px; height: 1px; padding-top: 190px; margin-left: 595px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: left; max-height: 170px; overflow: hidden;
display: inline-block; font-size: 10px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;
div.div: Nodes connect to the telemetry address and their connection is routed to the telemetry core process.
The core process stores chain-specific state, and routes messages to the relevant chain to update that state and send updates to feeds subscribed to that chain.
Feeds subscribe to chains and are routed to the relevant chain actor to receive updates from it.

switch.text: Nodes connect to the telemetry address and...

display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 212px; height: 1px; padding-top: 710px; margin-left: 595px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: left; max-height: 90px; overflow: hidden;
display: inline-block; font-size: 10px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;
div.div: Nodes connect to the telemetry address and their connection is routed to one of the available shards. On connection, they send "system connected" messages for each set of node information they wish to send out and then start sending updates about that node.

switch.text: Nodes connect to the telemetry address and...

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 212px; height: 1px; padding-top: 820px; margin-left: 595px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: left; max-height: 70px; overflow: hidden;
display: inline-block; font-size: 10px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;
div.div: One way or another, we'd like to distribute incoming connections across shards. Nodes will try to reconnect in a few seconds if they are disconnected.

switch.text: One way or another, we'd like to distribut...

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 212px; height: 1px; padding-top: 927px; margin-left: 595px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: left; max-height: 93px; overflow: hidden;
display: inline-block; font-size: 10px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;
div.div: Shards receive JSON telemetry from nodes. Their main task is to deserialize it, and send along to the Telemetry Core only data that it cares about, ignoring the rest. It re-serializes to a more compact format (bincode currently) to try and minimise bandwidth to the core.

switch.text: Shards receive JSON telemetry from nodes....

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 212px; height: 1px; padding-top: 1075px; margin-left: 595px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: left; max-height: 210px; overflow: hidden;
display: inline-block; font-size: 10px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;
div.div: The core process keeps track of the state of connected nodes as information comes in, and broadcasts relevant updates out to feeds. If tells shards to "mute" messages from nodes when there are too many nodes on a chain, or a chain on our deny list.
If this core process dies and restarts, shards will force nodes to reconnect after reconnecting to the core, so that they send out their "system connected" message again.
If a shard connection is lost, the core removes all knowledge of nodes connected via that shard, and broadcasts relevant updates to feeds.

switch.text: The core process keeps track of the state...

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 212px; height: 1px; padding-top: 1332px; margin-left: 595px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: left; max-height: 108px; overflow: hidden;
display: inline-block; font-size: 10px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;
div.div: Feeds are browsers that have connected to the telemetry core. Feeds get sent basic information about the chains that exist, and then tell the core what chain they want to subscribe to. The core keeps track of this and sends chain-specific messages only to interested feeds.

switch.text: Feeds are browsers that have connected to...

box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: center;

display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 212px; height: 1px; padding-top: 1827px; margin-left: 595px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: left; max-height: 133px; overflow: hidden;
display: inline-block; font-size: 10px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;
div.div: Shards connect to multiple telemetry core processes and clone messages to each of them. Potentially, we could "bucket" things based on genesis hashes, but an easy first step is to send all messages to every core.
If any of the connected "core" processes go down, we force nodes to reconnect when it comes back up, to get new uptodate "system connected" messages.

switch.text: Shards connect to multiple telemetry core...

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 212px; height: 1px; padding-top: 1999px; margin-left: 595px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: left; max-height: 65px; overflow: hidden;
display: inline-block; font-size: 10px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;
div.div: Each telemetry core process would have a complete state of the world, and work in the same way that it does in the current sharded approach.

switch.text: Each telemetry core process would have a c...

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 212px; height: 1px; padding-top: 2147px; margin-left: 595px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: left; max-height: 70px; overflow: hidden;
display: inline-block; font-size: 10px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;
div.div: Because we have multiple "core" processes with a complete state of the world, we can load balance connected feeds across them.

div.div: With shards, we remove the bottleneck on incoming node traffic. We could also "shard" the telemetry core process to help reduce the load from connected feeds if we find it is necessary (either by completely separate processes as this diagram shows, or multiple "loops" running inside a single telemetry core process to internally split feed connections across.)

switch.text: With shards, we remove the bottleneck on incoming node traffic. We could also "shard" the tele...

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 472px; height: 1px; padding-top: 640px; margin-left: 89px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: center; max-height: 62px; overflow: hidden;
display: inline-block; font-size: 10px; font-family: Helvetica; color: #000000; line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; word-wrap: normal;
div.div: With a single telemetry service, we have a bunch of data coming in to a single process, which pushed bandwidth limits and puts more pressure on the single process to handle deserialization and such. We can add shards to spread the load of handling the incoming message deserialization and bandwidth, and they can each strip away all unneeded info before passing it on to the core process.

switch.text: With a single telemetry service, we have a bunch of data coming in to a single process, which...
